Boundaries.title: Boundaries
Boundaries.about:
The Union Territory of Puducherry is extending over an area of 490 Sq.Kms. The U.T of Puducherry consists of two revenue districts viz., Puducherry District comprising of Puducherry, Mahe and Yanam regions and Karaikal District comprising of Karaikal region. There are 5 Municipalities, 10 Commune Panchayats, 8 Taluks and. Community Development Blocks. This map depicts the boundaries on Khandam, Municipality ward, Village, Taluk and district boundary of Puducherry.
On village boundary map, the details on each boundary area is projected with the base information such as number of villages, land parser, survey number with owner name, registration year and the area covered.

Source:DSTE, Puducherry
Boundaries.chapterheader: The Union Territory of India – Puducherry Boundaries

LULC.title: Land Use Land Cover
LULC.about:
The knowledge of Landuse / land cover changes is very important in understanding natural resources, their utilization, conservation and management. The physiographic map of the puducherry district presents more or less a flat land. The variation in the image characteristics like tone, texture, pattern etc. was used to identify various land use classes. These map depict the land use/land cover areas on Trees, shrub land, Grass land, Crop land, Built-up areas, Barren/Sparse Vegetation, Water and Wet land.

Source: National Centre for Coastal Research (NCCR), MoES)

Water Resources.title: Water Resources
Water Resources.about:
The Puducherry region is flat with average elevation of about 15 meters above sea level. This map depicts the flow of rivers and water bodies on puducherry region. There are fiver rivers namely: Gingee River (length of 34 km), Pennaiyar River (length of 6 km), Guduvaiuyar (length of 19.30 km), Pambaiyar (length of 13 km) and Malatar (length of 10 km). The Puducherry region is intersected by the deltaic channels of River Gingee and Pennaiyar and other streams forming the two main drainage basins, interspersed with lakes and tanks. River Gingee crosses the region diagonally from north-west to south-east, Pennaiyar forms the southern border and these rivers are rain fed. The water bodies of Puducherry region are Ousteri lake, Bahoor lake, Karasur lake, Thondamanatham lake, Ozhandai lake, Vadhanoor lake, Panayadikuppam lake, etc.,

Source:Source:DSTE, Puducherry

Water Quality.title: Water Quality
Water Quality.about:
The water quality can be monitored/analysed through the live Buoy (Buoy ID: 16600) deployed on Puducherry region. This buoy holds sensors that are our real-time eyes on the water. They transmit the data on considering the water-quality parameters such as Wind Speed, Wind Direction, Air Temperature, Humidity, Air Pressure, Water Temperature, Salinity, Dissolved Oxygen, pH, Turbidity, Chlorophyll, Phycoerythrin, Water Speed and Water Direction. These transmitted data can provide real-time information on current sea conditions and may increase accuracy for storm track and storm surge inundation models.

Source:NCCR

Marine Pollution.title: Marine_Outfall
Marine Pollution.about:
The marine outfall is graph-plotted for two locations: Kalapet and Thengaithittu considering the metals viz., cadmium, copper, mercury, zinc, lead, arsenic, chromium and pesticide, monocrotophos and other parameters. The graph plot shows that he Fe and Mn is abundant for class SW-III Waters and Pb and Cr is abundant for class SW-V waters. Trace amount of metals is essential micronutrients for the growth and metabolism of many organisms. However, metals in excessive amount can be toxic to organism and cause ecological toxicity.

Source: NCCR

Geomorphology.title: Geomorphology
Geomorphology.about:
The map shows the geomorphologic analysis of the development of topographic and bathymetric characteristics on the Puducherry region that were caused by physical, chemical, or biological processes. The variation in the image characteristics like tone, texture, pattern etc. was used to identify various geomorphology landforms. They are: the abandoned quarry, the beach, the beach ridge, the channel bar, the channel island, the deltaic plain, the creek network, the flood plain, the gullied land, the mangrove swamp, the Palaeo distributary, the pediment, the tidal flat, the tidal inlet, the WatBod river, etc.

Source:NCCR

Precipitation.title: Precipitation
Precipitation.about:
Precipitation is the product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapor that falls under gravitational pull from clouds. In simple, Precipitation is any liquid or frozen water that forms in the atmosphere and falls back to the earth. The graph depicts the precipitation data from 2010 to 2022.

Source:IMD

Humidity.title: Humidity
Humidity.about:
Humidity is a measure of the amount of water vapour in the air. Relative humidity measures the amount of water in the air in relation to the maximum amount of water vapour (moisture). The higher the temperature, the more water vapour the air can hold.

Source: IMD

Airtemperature.title: Airtemperature
Airtemperature.about:
The temperature of the air is a measure of how quickly the molecules are moving. The more energy of motion the molecules have, the higher the temperature you feel in the air. It is the most commonly considered weather parameter and measured in degrees Celsius (°C). The graph depicts the Air temperature of the Puducherry region from 2010 to 2022.

Wind speed is a fundamental atmospheric quantity caused by air moving from high to low pressure, usually due to changes in temperature. It affects the weather forecasting, aviation and maritime operations, construction projects, growth and metabolism rate of many plant species, and has countless other implications. The graph depicts the Wind speed of the Puducherry region from 2010 to 2022.

Source: IMD

Cloud Cover.title: Cloud Cover
Cloud Cover.about:
Cloud cover (also known as cloudiness or cloud amount) refers to the fraction of the sky obscured by clouds on average when observed from a particular location. Okta is the usual unit for measurement of the cloud cover. The cloud cover is correlated to the sunshine duration as the least cloudy locales are the sunniest ones while the cloudiest areas are the least sunny places, as clouds can block sunlight, especially on sunrise and sunset where sunlight is already limited. The graph depicts the cloud cover on the Puducherry region.

Source: IMD

Pressure.title: Pressure
Pressure.about:
Barometric pressure is the measurement of air pressure in the atmosphere, specifically the measurement of the weight exerted by air molecules at a given point on Earth. It is also known as air pressure. Low barometric pressure means the overlying air is rising, whereas high pressure means the overlying air is sinking. The graph depicts the barometric pressure on the Puducherry region.

Source: IMD

Wind Speed.title: Wind Speed
Wind Speed.about:
Wind speed is a fundamental atmospheric quantity caused by air moving from high to low pressure, usually due to changes in temperature. It affects the weather forecasting, aviation and maritime operations, construction projects, growth and metabolism rate of many plant species, and has countless other implications. The graph depicts the Wind speed of the Puducherry region from 2010 to 2022.

Source: IMD

Inundation Risk.title: Inundation Risk
Inundation Risk.about:
Coastal inundation caused by various natural hazards such as cyclones, storms, tsunamis, and floods depends on the coastal elevation and slope. However, the inundation level varies depending on the intensity of the hazard. The primary objective of Coastal Inundation Risk Mapping (CIRM) is to identify and mitigate the areas which are potentially at higher risk. This map is based on the risk of low-lying coastal areas exposed to coastal flooding on extreme water levels with respect to the multi-hazard line considering a 100-year return period. This also extended the scope towards approaching nature-based and grey-based protections. Further, the socio-economic data pertaining to each coastal village has been used to indicate the exposure to the inundation leading to a greater damage or risk.

Source:National Centre For Coastal Research, Ministry of Earth Sciences, Government of India

Coral Reefs.title: Coral Reefs
Coral Reefs.about:
Coral reefs provide as a source of food and novel medications, shield coasts from storms and erosive forces, stimulate the economy for nearby populations, and provide recreational activities. They also sustain healthy ocean food webs and provide habitats for millions of species of marine life. The coral reefs that exist in the Puducherry region are shown on this map.

Source: NCCR

Sandy Area.title: Sandy Area
Sandy Area.about:
Sand dunes offer essential ecological habitat as well as natural coastal defence against storm surge and strong waves, avoiding or minimising coastal flooding and structural damage. They serve as sand storage sites as well, delivering sand to beaches that have degraded. The map depicts the mapping of the various sand dunes on the Puducherry region.

Source: NCCR

Biodiversity Hotspots.title: Biodiversity Hotspots
Biodiversity Hotspots.about:
Biodiversity hotspots are ecologically unique regions that are exceptionally rich in species, and are thus priority targets for nature conservation. Biodiversity underpins all life on Earth, these hotspots have significant global value as they contain species and habitats that are found nowhere else. Their loss would mean loss of species and habitats that provide wild and farmed food, medicine and other materials and services such as climate regulation, pollination and water purification, all of which maintain the health of the ecosystems we depend upon.

Source: NCCR

Mangroves.title: Mangroves
Mangroves.about:
Shorelines are shielded by mangroves from the catastrophic storm and hurricane winds, waves, and floods. It also helps prevent erosion by stabilizing sediments with their tangled root systems. They maintain water quality and clarity, filtering pollutants and trapping sediments originating from land. This map demonstrates the growth of mangroves along the coast from 2013 to 2022.

Source: NCCR

Fish Potential Sites.title: Fish Potential Sites
Fish Potential Sites.about: Discovering and trapping fish is never an easy endeavour. Locating fish often requires investing a lot of effort and money. Fish potential spots are shown on this map of the Puducherry region. The fishing community will profit from this reliable and timely information on the potential fish aggregation zones since it will minimize the amount of time and effort needed to look for fish shoals.

Biological Production Hotspots.title: Biological Production Hotspots
Biological Production Hotspots.about:
The Marine Biodiversity including marine turtles in India is one among the richest in the Indian Ocean. Factors like climate change, unsustainable resource use, marine litter and pollution affect marine turtles and their habitats. Marine turtles play a variety of ecological roles for maintaining healthy marine habitats like controlling prey populations, supporting coastal vegetation through their hatchlings etc. Their presence is an indicator of healthy marine ecosystems and provides a source of revenue for local communities through tourism. Marine turtles thus present themselves as a key indicator of healthy marine habitats and an opportunity for conservation of associated species. The map depicts the plots of marine turtle nesting along the Puducherry region.

Source: National Centre For Coastal Research, Ministry of Earth Sciences, Government of India Source: National Marine Turtle Action Plan (2021-2026), Ministry of Environment, Forest & Climate Change, Government of India

Coastal Aquaculture.title: Coastal Aquaculture
Coastal Aquaculture.about:
Coastal aquaculture entails managed farming or culture of organisms in saline or brackish water areas for the purpose of enhancing production, both for domestic and export markets. The socio-economic benefits arising from aquaculture expansion include the provision of food, contributing to improved nutrition and health, the generation of income and employment, the diversification of primary production, and, increasingly important for developing countries, foreign exchange earnings, etc.

Source:NCCR

Surface Boat Sports.title: Surface Boats
Surface Boat Sports.about:
Some of the water sports are: Snorkeling, Surfing, Sailing, Canoeing, Wakeboarding, etc.

Source:NCCR

Coastal Inundation Risk.title: Coastal Inundation Risk
Coastal Inundation Risk.about:
Coastal inundation caused by various natural hazards such as cyclones, storms, tsunamis, and floods depends on the coastal elevation and slope. However, the inundation level varies depending on the intensity of the hazard. The primary objective of Coastal Inundation Risk Mapping (CIRM) is to identify and mitigate the areas which are potentially at higher risk. This map is based on the risk of low-lying coastal areas exposed to coastal flooding on extreme water levels with respect to the multi-hazard line considering a 100-year return period. This also extended the scope towards approaching nature based and grey based protections. Further, the socio-economic data pertaining to each coastal village has been used to indicate the exposure to the inundation leading to a greater damage or risk.

Source:NCCR & INCOIS

Mangroves Status.title: Mangroves Status
Mangroves Status.about:
Mangroves protect shorelines from damaging storm and hurricane winds, waves, and floods. It also helps prevent erosion by stabilizing sediments with their tangled root systems. They maintain water quality and clarity, filtering pollutants and trapping sediments originating from land. The graph plot on Mangrove area (Ha) indicates that the area accumulation on growth of mangroves along the sea-side is in incremental order for each and every year between 2015 to 2022. The map depicts the growth of mangroves along the sea-side between 2013 and 2022

Source: NCCR

Fisheries.title: Fisheries Status
Fisheries.about:
The World Travel and Tourism Council estimated that in 2018, tourism provided 8.1% of all employment in India, and generated 9.2% of India GDP. By 2028, the industry is expected to increase at an average annual rate of 6.9%, reaching $320 billion (or 9.9% of GDP). But still tourists are facing many infrastructure related problems like inadequate roads, water, hotels and telecommunications etc. Considering this, the regional developments should be taken into consideration for increasing the excellence of tourism in India. However, tourism industry places numerous stresses on regional ecosystems, leading to biodiversity loss, an increase in marine and beach litters, greenhouse gas emissions, and demand for more natural resources.

Source: Government Of Puducherry
Fisheries.subpara: Fishing is the traditional activity in India and it is one of the major sources of nutrition, employment and income for the coastal communities.

Tourism.title: Tourism Status
Tourism.about:
The World Travel and Tourism Council estimated that in 2018, tourism provided 8.1% of all employment in India, and generated 9.2% of India GDP. By 2028, the industry is expected to increase at an average annual rate of 6.9%, reaching $320 billion (or 9.9% of GDP). But still tourists are facing many infrastructure related problems like inadequate roads, water, hotels and telecommunications etc. Considering this, the regional developments should be taken into consideration for increasing the excellence of tourism in India. However, tourism industry places numerous stresses on regional ecosystems, leading to biodiversity loss, an increase in marine and beach litters, greenhouse gas emissions, and demand for more natural resources.

Source: Government Of Puducherry
Tourism.subpara: The tourism sector in India is an integral pillar of the Make in India program and it is growing rapidly. The tourism industry in India plays a role of significant economic multiplier and becomes critical since India has to grow at rapid rates and create jobs.

Vulnerability.title: Coastal Inundation Risk Atlas
Vulnerability.about:
Coastal inundation caused by various natural hazards such as cyclones, storms, tsunamis, and floods depends on the coastal elevation and slope. However, the inundation level varies depending on the intensity of the hazard. The primary objective of Coastal Inundation Risk Mapping (CIRM) is to identify and mitigate the areas which are potentially at higher risk. This map is based on the risk of low-lying coastal areas exposed to coastal flooding on extreme water levels with respect to the multi-hazard line considering a 100-year return period. This also extended the scope towards approaching nature based and grey based protections. Further, the socio-economic data pertaining to each coastal village has been used to indicate the exposure to the inundation leading to a greater damage or risk.

Source: NCCR

Fisheries vs Tourism.title: Fisheries/Tourism
Fisheries vs Tourism.about: Conflicts among the maritime uses and the environment have been analyzed based on the compiled spatial data of maritime activities.
Fisheries vs Tourism.subpara:
Tourism development leads to lower fishery participation but higher fishing intensity. So, tourism can affect the fisheries

Source: NCCR

Tourism vs Shoreline.title: Tourism/Shoreline
Tourism vs Shoreline.about: Conflicts among the maritime uses and the environment have been analyzed based on the compiled spatial data of maritime activities.
Tourism vs Shoreline.subpara:
Residence on the coastal zone, shipping, land-use and tourism practices can affect the shoreline.

Source: NCCR

Ecology vs Human Activities.title: Ecology/Human Activities
Ecology vs Human Activities.about:
Conflicts among the maritime uses and the environment have been analyzed based on the compiled spatial data of maritime activities.

Source: NCCR
